awd_titl_txt: Cognitive graphs: The geometry of spatial knowledge
awd_abstract_narration:
Being oriented in a new environment and finding and remembering the locations of resources are critical skills for human existence. When exploring a new city, tourists often wander through the streets, with the goal of visiting individual sites and taking in specific views. Through this wandering, they gain an understanding of the network of the city streets. When returning to their hotel, they are unlikely to retrace their steps. They also will not take a straight-line shortcut. Instead, they will draw on what they have learned about their environment to determine a path home using the city streets. How are tourists able to find their way back, based on experience alone, yet unable to determine a straight-line shortcut? This project addresses the challenging problem in the study of human navigation: What is the underlying geometric structure of our navigational knowledge? Is it truly a cognitive map, as is commonly assumed? Is it something coarser and more fluid? We propose that the underlying structure is a graph?a series of connections between places in a network, much like city streets. The overarching goal of this proposal is to test hypotheses about graph knowledge and its properties using walking virtual reality (VR) methods. Outcomes of this research have the potential to impact other fields, including robotics, neuroscience, mathematics, and geography. The interdisciplinary research proposed here will establish a deep understanding of the theory and cognitive mechanisms of spatial orientation, with far-reaching impacts. Greater knowledge of the basic properties of human navigational systems will lead to improved and more effective electronic navigation and GPS systems, self-driving vehicles, emergency response training, and transportation signage. Dr. Chrastil is committed to training the next generation of scientists and increasing the participation of underrepresented groups in STEM fields. As part of this proposal, Dr. Chrastil will develop a workshop on research methods for virtual reality to train researchers on this exciting technique. She actively participates as a teacher and mentor for programs that encourage participation of women and girls in science.

This project specifically tests the hypothesis that the most likely structure of navigational knowledge is a labeled graph, which incorporates local metric information but is not globally consistent across the environment. We have previously conducted an initial test of the idea of a cognitive graph, demonstrating that graph spatial knowledge is used preferentially rather than simply learning routes between locations (Chrastil & Warren, 2014). However, a systematic test of labeled graph knowledge has not been conducted. Little is known about how graph knowledge is constructed during learning or whether labeled graphs are used across all individuals and situations. Here, we propose a framework detailing the theoretical contributors to graph knowledge. We will also test the relationship between graph knowledge and other spatial knowledge taxonomies. In a series of experiments, we will use fully-immersive virtual reality to test hypotheses regarding the nature of spatial knowledge. First, we will characterize the nature of cognitive graphs by pitting labeled graph knowledge against other types of spatial knowledge and testing a primary prediction of labeled graph knowledge. Next, we will test the constraints on labeled graph knowledge, such as generalizability across contexts, its relationship to other taxonomies, and spatial preference. Finally, we will examine the mechanisms of learning labeled graph knowledge, in particular the deployment of attention and active decision making. This research cuts across levels of analysis by contrasting local and global levels of spatial understanding and by pitting labeled graphs against other spatial systems. The results of the proposed work will provide critical insight into the fundamental formation of human spatial knowledge and will contribute to the fields of robotics and neuroscience.

por.por_cntn:
This study addresses a challenging problem in the study of human navigation: What is the underlying geometric structure of our navigational knowledge? Is it truly a metric cognitive map—as is commonly assumed—or is it something coarser and more fluid? We propose that the underlying structure is a graph—a series of connections between network place nodes. In particular, the most likely structure is a labeled graph, which incorporates local metric information but is not globally consistent across the environment. We have previously conducted an initial test of the idea of a cognitive graph, demonstrating that graph spatial knowledge is used preferentially rather than simply learning routes between locations (Chrastil & Warren, 2014). However, a systematic test of labeled graph knowledge has not been conducted, and little is known about how graph knowledge is constructed during learning or whether labeled graphs are used across all individuals and situations. This study takes an interdisciplinary approach to develop and test a theoretical framework about the fundamental nature of human navigational knowledge. This theoretical innovation is systematically examined from multiple perspectives and across levels of analysis, including testing key predictions, establishing its limitations and generalizability, and determining the processes involved in constructing this knowledge.

The major goals of this project are to 1) test the hypothesis that the underlying structure of navigational spatial knowledge is a labeled graph, 2) establish the constraints and properties of labeled graph knowledge, and 3) determine the mechanisms that support the acquisition of graph knowledge.

The results of the work have provided critical insight into the fundamental formation of human spatial knowledge and will contribute to the fields of robotics and neuroscience. Our results actually suggest that graph knowledge may not necessarily be separate from survey knowledge (knowledge of distances and angles), because performance in tests of graph and survey knowledge are highly correlated. This finding suggests that graph knowledge may be different in quantity from survey knowledge, but might not be a fundamentally different type of spatial knowledge. Modulating attention to different properties of the environment or having people make predictions about their upcoming choices do not appear to facilitate learning. These results suggest that individual navigational abilities are not easily trained or improved.

On the other hand, we have made substantial headway in understanding how and why people choose particular routes. We have found that people tend to take different routes from A to B than they do from B to A. We found that people prefer to take routes with fewer turns in them even when the distance is the same, and that they are consistent in their preferences for other spatial properties. These findings suggest that people are sensitive to properties in the environment other than distance alone, and use those properties to make decisions about their travel.

This study utilizes the innovative method of fully-immersive virtual reality (VR) to probe questions that were previously intractable. Virtual environments (VEs) allow for full access to vestibular and proprioceptive information during navigation, which contribute to many aspects of navigational learning beyond vision alone, while maintaining both experimental control and ecological validity in realistic and immersive worlds. The use of VEs and development of mobile VR technology will provide opportunities to improve methodological and technological approaches across multiple disciplines, including transportation, fine arts, communications, psychology, geography, sociology, and physical sciences. Our lab has provided numerous tours as part of educational outreach for high school and college students to learn more about VR technology. Through a VR workshop on campus, we disseminated knowledge of this technique to other behavioral researchers. 

Researchers involved in this study have included undergraduate students, graduate students, lab managers, and postdoctoral scholars. The experiences have provided in-depth training for these researchers in areas such as experimental design, data analysis, programming, and writing.

The outcomes of this research will improve people’s daily lives by leading to improvements in wayfinding systems and signage, as well as autonomous systems and self-driving cars. Understanding human wayfinding is particularly relevant in conditions in which standard GPS systems are unavailable or unreliable, such as underwater, on the lunar or Martian surface, indoors, underground, or as backups for GPS failure. The ubiquity of wayfinding assistance/GPS devices could change how navigation is performed and alter spatial representations; this research will establish current human wayfinding styles and provide a baseline to test how GPS devices modify spatial representations. Greater knowledge of the basic properties of human navigational systems will lead to improved and effective electronic navigation systems, emergency response training, and transportation signage. Together, the methods and outcomes of this research promise to extend well beyond the specific scientific questions addressed here.
